title: The Accerditiation of 2 programs in Our Faculty of Education Has Been Extended
content: The Accerditiation of 2 programs in Our Faculty of Education Has Been Extended 12.05.2025 08.05.2025 The accreditation of two programs in Faculty of Education at Istanbul Sabahattin Zaim University has been renewed. The accreditation of Special Education Teaching Program has been extended until 2027, while Turkish Language Teaching Program has been extended until 2028. WHAT DOES ACCREDİTATİON MEAN? Accreditation is an external evaluation process that certifies compliance of University education programs with certain quality standards. Through this process, academic professional competencies of programs are assessed by independent organiziation. CONDUCTED UNDER THE SUPERVISION OF YÖKAK In Turkey, quality assurance system of higher education institutions are coordinated by Higher Education Quality Council (YÖKAK). Organizations authorized to grant accreditation operate according to criteria set by YÖKAK. EVALUATED BY EPDAD The teacher training programs at IZU were evaluated by Association for Evaluation Accreditation of Teacher Education Programs (EPDAD), a competent body in this field. EPDAD is recognized as a national accreditation institution foucsing on academic competency professional standards in teacher education programs. A GUARANTEE FOR STUDENTS AND APPLICANTS Thanks to accreditation, students can be assured that program they are enrolled in meets a certain quality standard. It also supports institutions in engaging in continuous improvement processes. The Faculty of Education at IZU offers undergraduate programs in Arabic Language Teaching, English Language Teaching, Preschool Teaching, Guidance Psychological Counseling, Special Education Teaching, Elementary Mathematics Teaching, Primary School Teaching, Turkish Language Teaching. These programs are also entitled to use Turkish Qualifications Framework (TQF) logo on their diplomas. Representing high quality standards in education employment both domestically internationally, TQF logo will be included on diploma supplements, graduation certificates, transcripts of students graduating from these programs as of 2023–2024 academic year.

title: “1st International, 2nd National Health Sciences Congress” Begins at IZU
content: “1st International, 2nd National Health Sciences Congress” Begins at IZU 07.05.2025 The “1st International, 2nd National Health Sciences Congress” , held under theme “Inclusivity Accessibility in Digital Health Era: Sustainable Solutions for All” , has officially begun at our university. The program, hosted at Abdullah Tivnikli Conference Hall, brought together numerous participants from academia, public institutions, healthcare sector. In his opening speech, IZU Rector Prof. Dr. Ahmet Cevat Acar shared remarks on Turkey’s healthcare system. Highlighting that Turkey is one of most socially oriented countries in world in terms of access to healthcare, Rector Acar said: “A Turkish citizen can go to highest-level hospital just for a headache. This is very valuable, but it also disrupts certain balances in system. Mechanisms like referral chain must be re-evaluated. Health is a vital field, state’s responsibility in this area is a requirement of being a social state.” BAHÇECİK: WE MUST DEVELOP INCLUSIVE SOLUTIONS Congress Chair Dean of IZU’s Faculty of Health Sciences, Prof. Dr. Ayşe Nefise Bahçecik, emphasized that digital health technologies are not merely innovations but essential tools for sustainability equity of health systems. Stressing that technology alone is not sufficient, she stated: “We must produce inclusive solutions by taking into account socio-economic inequalities access difficulties for elderly individuals with disabilities.” She also noted that congress would include discussions on how systems such as artificial intelligence, mobile health applications, remote patient monitoring could be integrated within ethical frameworks. KILIÇ: WE WILL SHAPE NOT JUST TODAY, BUT TOMORROW Op. Dr. Zülfü Kılıç, Head of Health Services at Istanbul Provincial Health Directorate, pointed out that digital transformation is not only a development but also a matter of management, saying: “Digitalization in health brings about revolutionary changes. However, this transformation does not only bring benefits; it also introduces new barriers, challenges, risks that must be managed. Platforms where academia practitioners work together are essential for a healthy future. The insights gained here will shape not only today but also tomorrow.” Throughout congress, both online in-person panel sessions are addressing topics ranging from AI-supported healthcare services to cross-cultural nursing. Regional health projects carried out by students, product competitions, scientific presentations are among program's highlights. The international event is conducted in both Turkish English, with simultaneous interpretation services provided.

title: Family Minister Mahinur Özdemir Göktaş Attended the 'Parenting Summit'
content: Family Minister Mahinur Özdemir Göktaş Attended 'Parenting Summit' 15.05.2025 10.05.2025 The Parenting Summit, held as part of IStanbul parent Academies project led by Istanbul Provincial Directorate of National Education, took place at Istanbul Sabahattin Zaim University. As part of summit, Minister of Family Social Services Mahinur Özdemir Göktaşn delivered a seminar. The summit was organized in collaboration Istanbul Parent Academies, Teacher Academies, Istanbul Sabahattin Zaim University. Held at The Abdullah Tivnikli Conference Hall on IZU's Halkalı Campus, event drew significant participation from educators officials, including Minister of Family Social Services Mahinur Özdemir Göktaş, IZU Rector Prof. Dr. Ahmed Cevat Acar, Istanbul Provincial Director of National Education Assoc. Prof. Dr. Murat Mücahit Yentür, District Governor of Küçükçekmece Mustafa Anteplioğlu. Minister Göktaş: A Peaceful Family is a Child's Most Fundamental Need As part of summit, Minister Mahinur Özdemir Göktaş delivered a seminar titeld "Peacful Family, Happy Child". Emphasizing critical role of family harmony in child development, she stated, “We all want to provide our children a good education a promising future, yet we often overlook their most fundamental need: to grow up love in a peaceful family environment.” Minister Göktaş added, “Family is about observation, patience, hearing silence between our children's words.” She continued: “A screen can never replace a mother’s compassion, a father’s attention, or a teacher’s touch. Through digital detox camps, we invite families to reconnect nature distance themselves from screens. Social media platforms must recognize their responsibility toward children; otherwise, we may have to adopt more radical measures. The greatest legacy one can leave a child is a peaceful home. The small but profound impressions we leave today will shape doctors, teachers, artists of tomorrow.” Rector Acar: We Must Preserve Traditional Family Structure In his opening speech, IZU Rector Prof. Dr. Ahmet Cevat Acar emphasized significance of Turkish family structure. “Employment models should be developed in harmony women's maternal roles,” he said. “We must establish work models that enable women—especially mothers—to participate in professional life without compromising their family responsibilities. The concept of a ‘family-friendly workplace’ is crucial in this regard.” Rector Acar further stated: “Family counseling programs launched in universities are important steps forward. As a university, we act this awareness. Two-thirds of our student body consists of female students, which is promising in terms of women's education societal contribution. The challenges faced by children raised outside family structure are evident. For future of our nation humanity, we must protect uphold institution of family.” Yentür: The Struggle We Undertake for Our Children is Most Sacred Battle Assoc. Prof. Dr. Murat Mücahit Yentür, Istanbul Provincial Director of National Education, described their efforts to guide children toward goodness, truth, justice, compassion following words: “I believe that to live is to fight for sake of children under a clear sky. As mothers, fathers, teachers, we engage in most sacred struggle to lead our children toward what is right. For most precious entity in this life is human being, their safest refuge is their mother, father, first school, first teacher. Unfortunately, today this safe haven—the family institution—is under intense attack from Western powers. However, ancient culture, faith, educational heritage of Anatolia are greatest forces to protect this fortress.” Following speeches, event continued a musical talk by Melihat Gülses, Necip Gülses, Neva Gülses, concluded workshop sessions.

title: MTG’25: The Future of Young Engineers Discussed
content: MTG’25: The Future of Young Engineers Discussed 15.05.2025 Organized by IEEE Student Club of Istanbul Sabahattin Zaim University (IZU), MTG’25 event not only provided students with valuable sectoral experience but also highlighted Turkey’s growing success in digital technologies. During event, IZU Rector Prof. Dr. Ahmet Cevat Acar emphasized Turkey’s advancements in defense industry and underscored importance of self-confidence in field of engineering. Held at Nizamülmülk Conference Hall, MTG’25 program opened with a keynote speech by Prof. Dr. Ahmet Cevat Acar. Referring to recent tensions between India and Pakistan, Rector Acar cited success of Turkey’s domestically developed CORAL system as a powerful example. “We saw more clearly in this incident how digital technologies can be effectively utilized in defense. Turkey has achieved significant milestones in defense industry over past 20 years,” he stated. Stressing critical role of young engineers, he added, “It is essential that Turkish engineers possess a strong sense of self-confidence.” Küçük: We Focused on Digital Campus IZU Vice Rector and Dean of Faculty of Engineering and Natural Sciences, Prof. Dr. İsmail Küçük, stated: “Our initial goal was to align students' graduation projects with industrial engineering applications while also fostering a professional network. This year, we adopted a different focus, turning our attention to concept of a digital campus.” The event also featured an inspiring talk by Mustafa Mertcan, Founder of DOF Robotics, on future of artificial intelligence and digital technologies. “Artificial intelligence shows us how we might be able to think in similar ways,” Mertcan said. Emphasizing importance of innovative approaches in education, he concluded: “We need to adopt a different perspective when it comes to education.” The program continued with student presentations of their graduation projects, offering them opportunity to showcase their technical expertise and receive direct feedback from industry professionals. MTG’25 provided a platform for students to reinforce their technical competencies, explore current industry practices, and establish one-on-one connections with professionals in field.

title: 2nd Graduate Student Congress Begins
content: 2nd Graduate Student Congress Begins 15.05.2025 The 2nd Graduate Student Congress , organized in collaboration between Istanbul Sabahattin Zaim University İlim Yayma Foundation, commenced at Abdullah Tivnikli Conference Hall. The opening ceremony was attended by IZU Rector Dr. Ahmet Cevat Acar, Vice Rectors Dr. İbrahim Güney Dr. Erhan İçener, İlim Yayma Foundation General Director İdris Tankut Küsmezer, along with numerous academics students. Delivering opening address, IZU Rector Dr. Ahmet Cevat Acar emphasized that congress serves not merely as an event but as a valuable academic platform. “This gathering not only strengthens social bonds but also offers an opportunity to showcase scientific potential of our country,” he noted. “I believe that with a focus on education in Turkish by implementing multi-purpose, well-planned initiatives, we can achieve even greater success.” Küsmezer: We Strive to Raise Virtuous Capable Individuals İlim Yayma Foundation General Director İdris Tankut Küsmezer highlighted foundation’s 75-year legacy of prioritizing support for education science. “We are doing everything within our power to nurture future scientists,” he said. İçener: Our Aim Is to Contribute Scientifically to Our University Vice Rector Dr. Erhan İçener reported that 47 papers were accepted for presentation this year, with participation from scholars students representing various universities. “Our congress has been enriched by diversity of submissions from different institutions,” he said. “A total of 47 papers were accepted. The sessions will contribute both to promotion of our university to academic advancement.” Opening Lecture Delivered by Dr. Zekai Şen On first day of event, opening lecture was delivered by Dr. Zekai Şen, a faculty member at Istanbul Medipol University recipient of Grand Prize of 2021 İlim Yayma Awards. In his talk, Şen emphasized importance of etymology, logic, conceptual thinking in conducting scientific research. “Civilization is not solely built on structures, but on development of human activity,” he stated. “Ancient civilizations that emerged around water resources laid foundations of technological progress.” Şen underscored historical relationship between civilization science. The congress will continue on Thursday, May 15, 2025.

title: A Cultural Mosaic at Zaim
content: A Cultural Mosaic at Zaim 15.05.2025 14.05.2025 The “Zaim Cultural Festival” held at Istanbul Sabahattin Zaim University brought together students from diverse regions of world for a vibrant enthusiastic celebration of cultural exchange. Organized in university’s Historic Courtyard, festival hosted students visitors representing 31 different countries. The event garnered significant attention from IZU’s academic administrative staff, as well as from a large number of students. The opening ceremony was conducted by IZU Rector Prof. Dr. Ahmet Cevat Acar, District Governor of Küçükçekmece Mustafa Anteplioğlu, Vice Rectors Prof. Dr. İsmail Küçük Prof. Dr. Erhan İçener, Head of Department of Health, Culture, Sports Hülya Şekerci, International Office Coordinator Nesibe Aloudatallah. Traditional Cuisine, Dances, Cultural Displays Emphasizing cultural diversity interaction, event featured country-specific booths where international students showcased their traditions through national attire, local cuisine, unique artifacts—offering visitors a figurative tour around world. The IZU Music Choir’s live performance added vibrancy to event, while musical dance performances by students from various countries received wide acclaim. Later in program, university’s Theater Club staged a well-received play titled Korkma (“Do Not Fear”), followed by a stage performance by Music Club. The Zaim Cultural Festival not only increased cultural awareness among students but also strengthened solidarity contributed to development of tolerance mutual understanding within university community.

title: Islamic Economics and Finance Forum Broadcast Live on TVNet
content: Islamic Economics Finance Forum Broadcast Live on TVNet 21.05.2025 Istanbul Sabahattin Zaim University (IZU) hosted a significant gathering in field of Islamic economics finance. The "Islamic Economics Finance Forum", which was broadcast live on TVNet, brought together leading academics experts in discpline. prominent figures from world of economics finance took part in TVNnet's live broadcast of program "Z Report". Moderated by Semra Karabaş held in Historic Building Museum Hall, forum featured insightful discussions on Islamic economics. Among participants were IZU Rector DR. Ahmet Cevat Acar, Ruşen Ahmet Albayrak, Yusuf Dinç, İbrahim Güran Yumuşak, Turan Erol, Servet Bayındır, Metin Toprak. Acar: Islamic Economics Offers a More Resilient Model Against Financial Crises IZU Rector Ahmet Cevat Acar emphasized growing interest in Islamic economics interest-free finance model both in Turkey around world. Rector Acar stated, "Islamic economics encompasses a framework that includes interest-free finance, participation banking, takaful (Islamic insurance). This system has been developing globally for nearly 40 years. In Turkey, structure was first institutionalized in 1983 with establishment of participation banks under name 'special finance institutions'." He continued: "As of today, there are approximately nine active participation banks in Turkey, holding a market share of around 9%. In field of Islamic insurance (takaful), four different companies are actively operating. Recently, digital participation banking has also become part of system. As a result, not only traditional participation banks but also digital interest-free financial institutions have entered market." Albayrak: We Are Not Pessimistic Ruşen Ahmet Albayrak, Deputy General Manager of Commerical Corporate Banking at Kuveyt Türk, remarked that participation banking is becoming increasingly aligned with global financial system is gaining strength. Albayrak stated, "There is no need for pessimism. The participation banking ecosystem is now fully integered with global markets. It possesses intellectual capacity capital strength to develop its own system, processes, products. With recent strong support from government development of capital insurance markets, we are moving towards designing a remarkable ecosystem." IZU Academics Convened at Forum Dean of Faculty of Economics Administrative Sciences, İbrahim Güran Yumuşak, emphasized importance of public universities supporting this field, stating: “We definitely need to raise awareness in this area.” Servet Bayındır, a faculty member in Department of Islamic Economics Finance, added, “If primary business activity is legitimate, financial operations are also legitimate, then we can confidently say, ‘This is a viable investment.’” Focusing on perception of wealth property in Islamic economics, IZU faculty member Metin Toprak stated: “Rather than a strict criterion of halal haram, this system promotes encouragement. Greed for wealth worldly gain is not praised in any religion. In Islam, those engaged in commercial activity are encouraged to uphold responsibilities towards society individuals.” Dinç: Orthodox Economics Is Flawed – There Is No Conflict with Gold IZU faculty member Yusuf Dinç highlighted significance of gold commented: “Our primary issue in integrating savings into financial system is ending conflict with gold. We are in constant conflict with gold, I believe this is unnecessary. That is why I criticize proponents of orthodox economics. The institution that ended this conflict in Turkey was Kuveyt Türk Participation Bank. Gold deposit accounts were introduced, numerous promotional campaigns were launched. Before Kuveyt Türk, no bank had advocated for this.”

title: Industry and Academia Discussed Intellectual Property Law at IZU
content: Industry Academia Discussed Intellectual Property Law at IZU 21.05.2025 The “Symposium on Current Developments in Intellectual Property Law 3rd International Symposium” commenced at Abdullah Tivnikli Conference Hall of Istanbul Sabahattin Zaim University (IZU). Speakers emphasized that protection of rights has become an increasingly complex issue in today’s globalized digitalized world, noting its critical role in motivating fostering creativity across diverse fields from academic production to music industry. The symposium was jointly organized by Istanbul Sabahattin Zaim University Balıkesir University. Opening speeches were delivered by IZU Rector Prof. Dr. Ahmet Cevat Acar, Balıkesir University Rector Prof. Dr. Yücel Oğurlu, Tashkent State University of Law Rector Prof. Dr. Islambek Rustambekov, International Vision University Rector Prof. Dr. Ahmet Vecdi Can, President of Turkish Patent Trademark Office Prof. Dr. Muhammed Zeki Durak, General Coordinator of Phonogram Producers' Collective Society of Turkey (MÜYAP) Bülent Forta, President of Musical Work Owners’ Society of Turkey (MESAM) Recep Ergül. Acar: Protecting Intellectual Property Is Becoming Increasingly Difficult In his opening remarks, IZU Rector Prof. Dr. Ahmet Cevat Acar stressed that in today’s rapidly digitalizing world, protection of has become more important than ever. He stated: “In this era of accelerated digitalization where digital materials, products, publications dominate questions remain about how to protect rights manage these processes. Ethical violations within academia, such as copyright infringement, are also part of this issue. Just as protecting tangible economic assets is crucial, safeguarding components such as patents, publications, copyrights is becoming increasingly complex especially under influence of globalization digital communication technologies.” Oğurlu: No Creative Work Can Be Produced Without Protection Balıkesir University Rector Prof. Dr. Yücel Oğurlu emphasized that protection of rights directly impacts creativity production. He remarked: “In countries where Turkey’s is not protected, production of original ideas works becomes impossible. We may spend nights, even weeks, creating just one sentence or paragraph. Among us are poets for whom completing a poem may take an entire year. But if that poem is stolen by someone else, we may lose motivation to ever write again. I personally witnessed how rightful expectations acquired rights were violated in a study I spent three years preparing. Such experiences inevitably weaken our motivation. If we fail to protect these ideals, we cannot set high academic goals, nor can we sustain productivity.” Durak: Companies Now Rely on Intellectual Property Assets President of Turkish Patent Trademark Office, Prof. Dr. Muhammed Zeki Durak, highlighted increasing significance of industrial such as patents, utility models, designs, geographical indications, trademarks in both national economy everyday life. He pointed to role of Turkey’s national technology initiatives growing interest among youth in driving development in this field, stating: “Young people are now asking themselves, ‘How can I invent something?’ Their self-confidence is growing.” He also noted that company valuations have shifted from being based on physical assets to assets. Forta: Legal Frameworks Must Adapt to Technological Developments Bülent Forta, General Coordinator of MÜYAP, drew attention to paradigm shift in music industry resulting from digitalization: “The world is undergoing a major transformation, paradigm shifts brought by digital music are rendering traditional mechanical regulations obsolete. We are now confronted with new phenomena such as podcasts, streaming services, artificial intelligence. The legal system must adapt to these developments. Technology advances first then law must follow. It is therefore essential that legal system provides fair effective solutions. The collaboration between universities industry will play a critical role in this digital transformation.” Ergül: Producers Assume All Risks MESAM President Recep Ergül emphasized challenges of music production crucial importance of property. He said: “The process of creating a song is akin to childbirth. A poet or composer may spend countless sleepless nights perfecting a work, often revising it repeatedly due to a pursuit of perfection. Eventually, a performer expresses interest in song, but without a producer, it cannot reach public. The producer assumes all risks, making a substantial financial investment while calculating potential losses.”

title: Scientific Approaches to the Origins of Language Discussed
content: Scientific Approaches to the Origins of Language Discussed 24.11.2025 The program titled “Scientific Pursuits in Addressing the Problem of the Origin of Language,” organized by the Department of Turkish Language Teaching, was held in Seminar Hall 2. Prof. Dr. Caner Kerimoğlu from Dokuz Eylül University attended as the keynote speaker and presented current scientific approaches to the emergence of language. Kerimoğlu emphasized that the origins of language cannot be explained solely through written sources and noted that disciplines such as biology, archaeology, and neuroscience also contribute significantly to this field of research. The conference concluded with a question and answer session attended by students and academics.

content: Architectural Traces of Hürrem Sultan 26.11.2025 The seminar "Haseki Hürrem Sultan's Architectural Works," organized by the Istanbul Sabahattin Zaim University Department of Architecture, was held in Seminar Hall 1 of the Historical Building. title: The issue of Ethics in Engineering
content: The issue of Ethics in Engineering 26.11.2025 The Engineering and Ethics Seminar organized by IZU Department of Industrial Engineering was held in Abdullah Tivnikli Conference Hall. In program, where Dr. Üzeyir Pala, faculty member of Industrial Engineering Department, served as speaker, topics such as origins of engineering and ethical concepts, framework and importance of professional ethics, points where science and philosophy intersect or diverge, and consequences of unethical professional practices were discussed. In his talk, Pala explored questions such as: "Is everything legal necessarily ethical?", "Who is an engineer?", "What is engineering ?", "What are ethics, morality, and virtue, and how do they function at different stages?"

content: A "Silent Cry" Against Violence Toward Women 26.11.2025 The "Silent Cry" exhibition, organized by the IZU Department of Architecture, opened for visitors in the Museum Hall of the Historical Building. Open until the evening of Wednesday, November 26, the exhibition seeks to raise societal awareness of violence against women.

title: IZU Cinema Club Hosted Director Mesut Uçakan
content: IZU Cinema Club Hosted Director Mesut 05.11.2025 Celebrated film director Mesut met with Istanbul Sabahattin Zaim University students. Following a screening of film Reis Bey , engaged in a talk session, answering students' question about film cinematic career. Known for memorable films from 1990s suchj as Reis bey , Kelebekler Sonsuza Uçar , Yalnız Değilsiniz, Ölümsüz Karanfiller, Mesut was hosted by Istanbul Sabahattin Zaim University. The Program titled "Behind Screen: Reis Bey Mesut Uçakan," organized by IZU Cinema Club, took place at Abdullah Tivnikli Conference Hall. Participants had opportunity to watch 1988 film Reis Bey, adapted from Necip Fazıl Kısakürek's theatrical work of same name, later listen to a talk by film's director. "THE SUCCESS OF REIS BEY STEMS FROM THE DEPTH NECIP FAZIL BROUGHT TO THE STORY" Speaking at event, which was attended by IZU Vice Rector Prof. Dr. Nihat Erdoğmuş along with academic administrative staff students, responded to question about Reis Bey cinematic journey. Explaining film continues to attract interest despite yerars have passed, attributed its success to profound depth Necip Fazıl brought to narrative. Reis Bey is work in which Master most clearly expresses Islam’s saving role,” he said, adding all of Necip Fazıl’s works serve this vision. “I HAVE BEEN INTERESTED IN LITERATURE AND CINEMA SINCE SECONDARY SCHOOL” Sharing interest in literature cinema began during secondary school years, noted he dreamed of making Reis Bey even at time. He continued, “The Master’s life story is story of Turkey’s cultural transformation. Therefore, adapting works to cinema was a significant necessity. We completed script for Reis Bey with minimal alterations, making only small revisions to its powerful narrative, then filmed it.” “I FACED FINANCIAL CHALLENGES AT EVERY STAGE OF MY FILMS” Recounting move to Istanbul for university, where he first became involved in journalism later cinema, emphasized influence of National Turkish Students Union (MTTB) Cinema Club on career. Describing those years as a period of “scarcity,” he stated he attempted to make films with “ideological consciousness” in an industry he believed was dominated by Hollywood influence. Sharing he addressed politically sensitive subjects such as headscarf bans, unsolved political murders, Hat Reform, he openly embraced a religious identity, explained he faced severe financial difficulties at every stage of film production could not fully realize cinematic vision due to budget constraints.

title: The 2019 İlim Yayma Awards Winners Met with Doctoral Students
content: The 2019 İlim Yayma Awards Winners Met with Doctoral Students 03.11.2025 The scholars who received İlim Yayma Awards in 2019 met with doctoral students at Istanbul Sabahattin Zaim University (IZU). Over a two-day program, academics shared their experiences insights with their young colleagues. Istanbul Sabahattin Zaim University hosted event titled “Experience Speaks,” which brought together recipients of İlim Yayma Awards doctoral students. The program, held in IZU Museum Hall, was attended by IZU Rector Ahmet Cevat Acar, Chairman of İlim Yayma Awards Commission İdris Sarısoy, Member of İlim Yayma Awards Academic Commission Assoc. Rahman Dağ. During event, Fikrettin Şahin, recipient of 2019 Grand İlim Yayma Award, Mehmet Zahmakıran, winner of Engineering, Natural, Health Sciences Award, İlyas Kemaloğlu, winner of Social Sciences Award, shared their academic experiences perspectives with doctoral students from various universities. ŞAHİN: “True Independence Requires Reducing External Dependence” Speaking at a session moderated by IZU Rector Ahmet Cevat Acar, Fikrettin Şahin emphasized that for a country to be truly independent, it must reduce its reliance on external sources. “We aim to achieve new developments by investing in biotechnology. In this regard, scientists bear significant responsibilities,” he said. ZAHMAKIRAN: “The Key to Success Is Curiosity a Desire for Lifelong Learning” Mehmet Zahmakıran highlighted that curiosity a continuous desire to learn are at heart of being a successful scientist. He stated: “If you want to become a good scientist, you must constantly ask yourself ‘why?’. Set realistic goals. When improving your foreign language skills, don’t just study to pass exams-learn to truly understand.” KEMALOĞLU: “The Perception of History Has Changed” İlyas Kemaloğlu drew attention to digital transformation in field of history. “The perception of history has changed thanks to academic research. Digital history studies have taken historical research to an entirely new level,” he said, emphasizing importance of language in historical studies. He noted that research meticulously examining local elements reveals valuable new insights about culture geography of regions studied. “Lantern Night Tour” at Yedikule Dungeons On second day of program, participants visited Sultanahmet Mosque, Hagia Sophia Grand Mosque, Gülhane Park, Spice Bazaar, accompanied by award-winning academics. The gathering concluded with a “Lantern Night Tour” held at Yedikule Dungeons.

title: Strategic Cooperation Protocol Signed Between IZU and the Turkish Maarif Foundation
content: Strategic Cooperation Protocol Signed Between IZU and Turkish Maarif Foundation 17.11.2025 A comprehensive cooperation protocol was signed between Istanbul Sabahattin Zaim University and Turkish Maarif Foundation with aim of strengthening mutual collaboration and enhancing academic solidarity in field of education. The signing ceremony was attended by Istanbul Sabahattin Zaim University Rector Prof. Dr. Ahmet Cevat Acar and Turkish Maarif Foundation President Mahmut Özdil . IZU Vice Rector Prof. Dr. İsmail Küçük and International Students Coordinator Nesibe Aloudatallah Ghadban were also present at ceremony. The protocol represents a strategic step toward advancing shared goal of both institutions to contribute to high-quality education on a global scale. Within scope of agreement, more than 70,000 students in 56 countries where Turkish Maarif Foundation operates will be provided with scholarship opportunities and avenues for academic development. In addition, protocol aims to foster sustainable cooperation between two institutions by developing educational programs aligned with IZU’s academic infrastructure and international vision, guiding students toward higher education opportunities in Türkiye, and enhancing joint initiatives in field of education.

title: "The Congress on Seeking Solutions to Crises in Europe and Central Asia" Held at IZU
content: "The Congress on Seeking Solutions to Crises in Europe Central Asia" Held at IZU 17.11.2025 At congress, solution proposals for political, social, economic crises experienced across a vast geography stretching from Turkistan to Balkans were discussed, a search for a common vision was evaluated within framework of "ASRICA" Islamic Union Model." Held at Abdullah Tivnikli Conference Hall of Istanbul Sabahattin Zaim University, “Congress on Seeking Solutions to Crises in Region of European Central Asian Islamic States” began with participation of representatives from twelve countries a large audience. The opening of congress, organized by Justice Defenders Strategic Research Center (ASSAM), was attended by many institutional organizational representatives, including Kütahya Dumlupınar University Rector Prof. Süleyman Kızıltoprak, International Balkan University Rector Prof. Lütfi Sunar, Erzurum Atatürk University Rector Prof. Ahmet Hacımüftüoğlu, Gaziantep Islamic Science Technology University Rector Prof. Şehmus Demir, Istanbul Sabahattin Zaim University Vice Rector Prof. Erhan İçener, AK Party Deputy Chairman of Election Affairs Prof. Veysel Ayhan, ASSAM President Melih Tanrıverdi, TGTV President İsmail Tuğrul, AfroAsia Universities Union Director Prof. Ashraf Abdel Rafea Al Darfaili, Islamic Scholars Foundation Board Member Prof. Mustafa Karataş, ASDER Board Member Cemal Erdoğan, Union of NGOs of Islamic World Board Member İbrahim Altan. The congress addressed political instabilities, identity border disputes, major-power competition in Turkistan, along with efforts to find solutions to religious, political, ethnic issues in Cyprus Balkans. Throughout sessions, possibilities of establishing a new vision for region’s countries within framework of ASRICA Islamic Union Model were discussed. In addition to Türkiye, representatives of civil society organizations from twelve countries including Qatar, Malaysia, Kosovo, Sudan shared their observations field experiences. The program also featured contributions from academics from participating countries, who provided scientific perspectives on topic.

title: Sumud Activists Meet with IZU Students
content: Sumud Activists Meet with IZU Students 17.11.2025 Sumud Fleet activists İkbal Gürpınar Umut Aslan, who set out to draw attention to Israel’s genocide in Gaza to break blockade, met with IZU students. The program “Sumud Experiences from Travelers of Resistance,” organized by Istanbul Sabahattin Zaim University’s Ahdimiz Kudüs Platform , was held at Abdullah Tivnikli Conference Hall. The event featured Sumud activists İkbal Gürpınar Umut Aslan as speakers was attended by IZU Rector Prof. Dr. Ahmet Cevat Acar, Vice Rector Prof. Dr. Nihat Erdoğmuş, faculty members, students. ACAR: “THE ISLAMIC WORLD IS THE TARGET OF THE WEST” Opening discussion, IZU Rector Prof. Dr. Ahmet Cevat Acar highlighted that with collapse of bipolar world in 1990s, West set its sights on Islamic world. Acar noted that despite difficulties faced, Sumud Fleet represented a very important initiative thanked all activists who risked their lives on this dangerous journey. He continued: “Zionist Israel continues its attacks despite ceasefire, its patrons openly maintain their support. Over two billion Muslims have not gone beyond merely observing what has happened over past two years. Our country has certain initiatives, many of which remain out of public eye; however, they are not sufficient. This is because ummah has not achieved unity.” GÜRPINAR: “I DID NOT HESITATE WHEN I WAS INVITED TO JOIN SUMUD” Television host author İkbal Gürpınar , who described herself as a mufti’s daughter an imam hatip high school graduate, admitted that she became well-informed about Palestine, Jerusalem, Al-Aqsa later in life. She shared her memories from trips to Palestine her Sumud experience. Gürpınar asked participants: “How can you tell if a country is free?” She explained that Palestinians who have no army, currency, industry, or travel rights derive their freedom from their strong faith. Reflecting on her invitation to join Sumud Fleet, she said: “A few weeks earlier, I had broken my shoulder, my arm was in a sling. Yet I did not hesitate to participate. My only question was: ‘Will they accept me?’ We were supposed to depart next day, but we were held in Tunisia for 13 days. Our captains were threatened, their licenses revoked, our ships sabotaged. On day of departure, only 13 of 50 ships could set sail. Everyone had a single goal: to break blockade.” ASLAN: “DON’T LET GAZA FALL OFF YOUR AGENDA” Businessman Sumud activist Umut Aslan said that a new path of resistance has emerged over past two years. He explained that Gaza resistance marked a turning point in his life, noting that he has been to Jerusalem twice in last two years now divides his life into “before Jerusalem” “after Jerusalem.” Pointing to Türkiye’s important role in struggles of Palestinians other oppressed peoples, Aslan advised young people: “Do not let Gaza fall off your agenda. Make space for one more file in your daily schedule name it ‘Jerusalem Gaza.’ Pass on this cause which you support today to your children as well.”

title: The Future of Family Businesses Discussed at IZU
content: The Future of Family Businesses Discussed at IZU 17.11.2025 The Family Business Sustainability Workshop was held at IZU. At international workshop organized in cooperation with Turkish Academy of Sciences (TÜBA) Kyoto Sangyo University, senior representatives from Türkiye’s leading owned companies Ziylan Group, Yıldız Holding, Sinpaş Real Estate Investment Trust, Eksim Holding, Kale Group, Hayat Holding shared their institutionalization stories experiences with participants. The international workshop titled “Sustainability Family Business: From Past to Present,” jointly organized by TÜBA Kyoto Sangyo University, took place at Istanbul Sabahattin Zaim University’s Abdullah Tivnikli Conference Hall. The workshop, which focused on sustainability of businesses, was attended by TÜBA President Prof. Dr. Muzaffer Şeker, IZU Rector Prof. Dr. Ahmet Cevat Acar, TÜBA Sustainable Development Finance Working Group Coordinator IZU Faculty Member Prof. Dr. Mehmet Bulut, IZU Vice Rector Prof. Dr. Nihat Erdoğmuş, Ziylan Group Chairman Mehmet Büyükekşi, former Chairman of Yıldız Holding Ali Ülker, Board Member of Sinpaş REIT Mahmut Çelik, Eksim Holding Chief Financial Officer Bora Çermikli, Kale Group Senior Advisor Yalçın Yılmazkaya, Hayat Holding Vice President for Eurasia Americas Enes Çizmeci, along with academics businesspeople from Türkiye abroad. BULUT: THE WORLD’S OLDEST FAMILY BUSINESS IS IN JAPAN Speaking at opening, Prof. Dr. Mehmet Bulut reminded participants businesses around world face sustainability challenges alongside financial environmental issues. Noting oldest business in world is located in Japan, Bulut added: “This six hundred year old company in Japan is followed by others established in France, Italy, Germany. The oldest business in Türkiye is Şekerci Hacıbekir, founded in eighteenth century. The average lifespan of companies in our country is about thirty years. Their most significant challenge is sustainability.” IZU Rector Prof. Dr. Ahmet Cevat Acar also emphasized uncontrolled consumption has pushed natural resources to brink of depletion since Industrial Revolution. “The vast majority of businesses begin as enterprises. Those overcome sustainability challenges through institutionalization continue to exist,” he said. “SUSTAINABILITY IS AS IMPORTANT FOR SOCIETIES AS IT IS FOR INDIVIDUALS” TÜBA President Prof. Dr. Muzaffer Şeker stated workshop aims to address question of “How can businesses preserve their strengths values sustain their existence?” He added: “Sustainability is important not only for individuals but also for societies. Through examples from countries such as Türkiye, Japan, Finland, Germany, Indonesia, we will identify local global factors contribute to success.” FROM ONE PAIR OF SHOES A DAY TO 100,000 PAIRS DAILY In workshop’s first session, senior representatives of Türkiye’s leading businesses shared their experiences. Ziylan Group Chairman Mehmet Büyükekşi described how his uncle Ahmet Muktad Ziylan started company sixty-five years ago in Gaziantep by producing one pair of shoes per day, how it has grown into a company with 800 stores in 24 countries across three continents, producing 100,000 pairs daily in 2023. “Our guiding principles have never changed: hard work, honesty, innovation, work ethic, a sense of responsibility to our customers. Ziylan Group grew around these values,” he said. ÜLKER: THE GROWTH OF COMPANIES IS SIMILAR TO HUMAN DEVELOPMENT Former Chairman of Yıldız Holding, Ali Ülker, summarized eighty-year journey of Ülker brand founded by his grandfather Sabri Ülker in 1944. He noted Ülker has always embraced principle “Make people happy, you will be happy.” Comparing companies’ growth stages to human life, Ülker said, “A child who learns to walk advances with baby steps frequent falls. Family businesses also do not begin professionally; they learn gain experience through trial error.” ÇELİK: WE PRODUCE NOT ONLY BUILDINGS BUT ALSO TRUST Sinpaş Holding Board Member Mahmut Çelik said business, founded by his uncle Avni Çelik in 1974, has expanded beyond construction into energy tourism. Citing Avni Çelik’s words, “We build not only buildings but also trust,” he highlighted importance of values passed down through generations noted early professionalization played a key role in their sustained success. ÇERMİKLİ: 90% OF FAMILY BUSINESSES DO NOT SURVIVE Eksim Holding CFO Bora Çermikli began by recalling Tivnikli started with flour production in 1980s now exports flour to more than forty countries. The group entered energy sector in 2000s is now Türkiye’s third-largest wind energy producer. Noting rapidly growing institutions inevitably face challenges, he emphasized management sustainability are most critical. He also stated 90% of businesses in Türkiye do not survive beyond second or third generation, underscoring importance of workshop. “ANYONE CAN DO THE EASY THING YOU TRY THE HARD ONE!” Kale Group Senior Advisor Yalçın Yılmazkaya shared story of Kale Group, founded in 1957 in Çanakkale’s Çan district. He noted founder, İbrahim Bodur, adopted principle of reflecting profit back into society. Quoting Bodur’s advice, “Anyone can do easy thing try hard one,” Yılmazkaya said this principle guides Kale Group’s investments in areas such as turbojet engines national infantry rifles. WHAT ROLE WILL THE NEXT GENERATIONS PLAY? The final speaker of opening session was Hayat Holding Board Member Enes Çizmeci, a fourth-generation representative of group. He explained company founded by Kiğılı brothers in 1937 now operates in seventeen countries. “The vital question for us is this: our grandfathers founded business, our fathers manage it what will third fourth generations do?” he said, highlighting importance of strong values, education, gaining experience. “As companies institutionalize, we too have become professional employees. We report our work remain accountable,” he added. In afternoon sessions, participants discussed sustainability perspectives of businesses their transformation from past to present, drawing on examples from around world.

title: Innovations and Applications of Artificial Intelligence Discussed at IZU
content: Innovations Applications of Artificial Intelligence Discussed at IZU 19.11.2025 At a program organized by Department of Computer Engineering, innovations application examples of artificial intelligence ranging from healthcare to space technologies, architecture to vehicle safety were thoroughly explored. The “Artificial Intelligence Social Transformation” seminar, hosted by Istanbul Sabahattin Zaim University Department of Computer Engineering, took place in Historical Building’s Museum Hall. In program, where IZU faculty members Prof. Dr. Tarık Özkul Assoc. Prof. Dr. Cevat Reşit served as speakers, students from Türkiye, Morocco, France presented project examples demonstrating use of artificial intelligence. The first talk of program was delivered by IZU Computer Engineering Faculty Member Prof. Dr. Tarık Özkul. Stating that he works with artificial intelligence both as an academic as a technology company executive, Özkul shared with students innovations introduced by five AI technologies implemented by his company. The AI applications developed by Özkul’s company operating at IZU Zaim Technopark, honored with numerous international awards, are used in fields of healthcare, wind turbines, satellite technologies, structural health monitoring, solar energy. Highlighting that “Artificial intelligence offers effective, fast, practical possibilities for problem detection solution development,” Özkul noted that they achieved 97% success in AI-supported vertigo treatment. Using Artificial Intelligence to Detect Conflicts of Interest In his talk titled “A Blockchain NLP-Based Multi-Layered Framework for Conflict of Interest Detection in Peer Review,” Assoc. Prof. Dr. Cevat Reşit presented their systematic literature review on technological procedural approaches to conflict of interest management. Reşit emphasized that conflict of interest remains a persistent issue in scientific peer review, as undisclosed or hidden relationships can undermine fairness. He provided following information about blockchain-based framework they propose: “Our systematic literature review reveals advances in metadata-based conflict of interest detection, reviewer assignment optimization, ethical frameworks, while also highlighting persistent gaps such as limited transparency in context-aware relationship identification, multi-dependency tracking, reporting mechanisms. The framework we propose addresses these limitations offers a multilayered conflict of interest detection model.” The full-day program concluded with presentations delivered by participants including guest students from Morocco France on following topics: “Peer Review Systems Conflicts of Interest” “From Draft to Publication: A Practical Guide for Successful Research Publishing” “Modeling Simulation of Respiratory System During Pressure-Controlled Mechanical Ventilation” “Optimizing Energy Efficiency in Buildings Using AI-Supported Digital Twins”

title: Taha Kılınç Spoke About East Turkestan at IZU
content: Taha Kılınç Spoke About East Turkestan at IZU 19.11.2025 Journalist author Taha Kılınç, who documented trip to East Turkestan-where religious cultural identity is being systematically eroded under intense pressure from China region remains largely isolated from world shared experiences of Uyghur people during talk at IZU. Kılınç was guest of program "Our Route: East Turkestan." During talk, which was also attended by IZU Rector Prof. Dr. Ahmet Cevat Acar, he shared observations from visit to region, based on book "In Pursuit of a Lost Geography: A Travelouge of East Turkestan." ACAR: "East Turkestan Is a Bleeding Wound of Islamic World" In opening speech, IZU Rector Prof. Dr. Ahmet Cevat Acar stated East Turkestan is one of bleeeding wounds of Islamic geography. Acar said: "The issue of East Turkestan is a topic world does not pay enough attention to. twenty million of our fellow believers kinsmen are under servere oppression. It is crucial to employ every possible means to make their voices heard to ease their suffering." KILINÇ: “We Were Asked Same Questions Israel Asks at Border” Speaking at talk moderated by SKS Department Head Hülya Şekerci, Taha Kılınç explained although he has been studying Islamic world for years, he was unable to travel to East Turkestan due to China’s visa entry restrictions. When he learned last year grey green passport holders no longer required visas, he began preparing for trip. Kılınç shared experiences from eight-day journey across 15 cities: “We were stopped at every step. The most common questions we faced were: ‘Who are you?’, ‘How do you know about these places?’, ‘Do you know anyone here?’ These were almost identical to questions Israel asks people traveling to Palestine.” Kılınç stressed security measures in region have reached extraordinary levels: “On poles placed every 10–15 meters, there are five or six cameras see in all directions record sound. Chinese officials identify families stay in their homes for 10–15 days for inspection. Those deemed necessary are taken to camps ‘trained.’” “Mosques Are Closed, Hijab Is Banned!” Pointing to silence in streets, anxiety of people, significant obstacles to foreigners entering region, Kılınç stated East Turkestan has been isolated from world for 15 years. He noted he did not see a single woman wearing hijab during visit emphasized China’s social engineering project designed to detach Uyghurs from their religion culture. He listed several restrictions: “It is forbidden to purchase tents, binoculars, telescopes, or ropes above a certain length. A Uyghur cannot stay away from home for more than three days. Mosques are closed, call to prayer is not allowed. Those under 18 cannot enter mosques, but in practice, we did not see anyone under 60 being allowed inside. The last Eid prayer in Kashgar was performed in 2016.” In program, which drew great interest from students, Kılınç stated China uses its economic power to block potential solutions emphasized civil society organizations must pressure governments into action. Following talk, Kılınç signed books at TDV Book Café.

title: “Architecture and Context” Discussed at IZU
content: “Architecture and Context” Discussed at IZU 24.11.2025 The program “Architecture and Context,” organized by the IZU Department of Architecture, was held at the Abdullah Tivnikli Conference Hall. The event featured Assoc. Prof. Dr. Rıfat Gökhan Koçyiğit , faculty member at Mimar Sinan Fine Arts University, Department of Architecture, and was attended by IZU architecture faculty members and students. Koçyiğit analyzed context , one of the fundamental concepts of architectural theory, within a broad framework ranging from the philosophy of language to epistemology, and from urban planning to design processes, addressing both its semantic and pragmatic dimensions. “Reality cannot always be grasped directly; it reveals different faces depending on circumstances. Therefore, an architect must learn to doubt, question, and interpret context from multiple perspectives,” he said. Koçyiğit also emphasized that the physical context consisting of elements such as solid void balance, texture, scale, and urban organization serves as a key determinant of any architectural project.

title: The Effects of Diabetes on Professional Life Were Discussed
content: The Effects of Diabetes on Professional Life Were Discussed 24.11.2025 At symposium titled "Diabetes Well Being at Work: Know More, Do More," organized by IZU Department of Nursing, relationship between diabetes professional life was evaluated within a scientific framework. Hosted by Istanbul Sabahattin Zaim University Faculty of Health Sciences, Department of Nursing, symposium took place at Abdullah Tivnikli Conference Hall with participation of academics students. ACAR: HEALTHY INDIVIDUALS ARE THE FOUNDATION OF A COUNTRY'S WORKFORCE CAPACITY Delivering opening speech of symposium, IZU Rector Prof. Dr. Ahmet Cevat Acar stated that diabetes has become a global health issue. Acar said: "Particularly in recent years, data show that diabetes is becoming increasingly prevalent in society. Factors such as an aging population, reduced physical activity, unbalanced nutrition significantly contribute to this rise. This indiates that diabetes is not merely a medical issue; it directly affects employee health, workforce productivity, economic performance of counries. Healthy individuals are fundamental component of a nation's workforce capacity. Moreover, development of digital technologies transformation of working models have made management of chronic diseases even more crucial." BAHÇEÇİK: DIABETES IS NOT JUST A MEDICAL ISSUE Dean of Faculty of Health Sciences, Prof. Dr. Ayşe Nefise Bahçeçik, emphasized that diabetes is not solely a medical matter, especially within today's repidly changing work models. She noted: "Individuals within diabetes spectrum make up significant portion of global workforce. It is essential to examine relationship between diabetes working life from a s scientific perspective. Diabetes Management in workplace encompasses a wide range of areas, including corporate health policies, workplace based training programs, promotion of healthy lifestyle behaviors, stress burnout management, interdisciplinary monitoring models." As part of program, Prof. Dr. Taner Damcı from Istanbul University Cerrahpaşa Medical Faculty Hospital presented "Diabetes Working Life: 2025 Perspective," Specialist Nurse Alev Kahraman presented “Nursing Support in Return-to-Work Process for Individuals with Diabetes,” Nurse Tuğba Yola delivered a presentation on “The Importance of Nutrition Exercise in Workplace,” Prof. Dr. Zeynep Oşar Sıva shared her presentation titled “Diabetes Monitoring Through Digital Health Technologies.”

title: IZU Leadership Change

title: IZU Students Condemn the Genocide in Gaza on the Second Anniversary of October 7th
content: IZU Students Condemn Genocide in Gaza on Second Anniversary of October 7th 22.10.2025 On Second anniversary of October 7th, IZU students protested Israel's attacks on Gaza. Gathering at university's campus in Halkalı, students held a march issued a press statement, calling for concete steps to stop genocide. Since start of Israel's heavy bombardment of Gaza following October 7, 2023, Al-Aqsa Flood operation, attacks have escalated to genocidal levels, sparking worldwide protests. On this second anniversary, IZU students gathered at Halkalı campus to condemn Israel's atrcities in Gaza. "Sumud: An Expression of Humanity's Shared Values" Students, who marched from ISEFAM building, made their press statement at IZU Square. IZU Rector Prof. Dr. Ahmet Cevat Acar, Vice Rectors, faculty members joined students. The statement highlighted Sumud fleet, which set sail with volunteers from 44 countries, as a symbol of resistance shared human values. The intervention against fleet was condemned, with statement stating: “People facing poverty, thirst, hunger under Israeli oppression are waiting hopelessly for international aid, while struggling against death. The countries complicit in this genocide, led by US, have forgotten human values for their own interests, becoming accomplices in this atrocity. It's time for concrete steps from Islamic countries to stop these brutal attacks.” Gazan Student: Silence Neutrality Must End Gazan student Ibrahim Reyen reminded that solidarity shouldn’t just be about slogans. He stated, “Let’s stand together against this machine of oppression. Let’s shout to world: ‘Gaza is not alone. We are with it until occupation ends Palestine is free from sea to river!’ There should be no silence anymore. There should be no neutrality in face of spilled blood.” Acar: Humanity is Watching Gaza Massacre Prof. Dr. Ahmet Cevat Acar expressed that world has been watching ongoing Israeli oppression since 1948 and, for last two years, genocide with helplessness. He said, “Humanity is watching Gaza massacre. International unity values have lost all meaning. Gaza’s people continue to sacrifice their lives to preserve humanity.” He thanked students for their sensitivity to Gaza encouraged them to work hard to excel in every field. Panel: “A Turning Point in Conflict: From October 7th to Today” IZU’s Political Science Club held a panel discussing impact of October 7th attack. Dr. Fadi Zatari spoke about Israeli propaganda, Dr. Selim Sezer highlighted issues faced by Palestinians outside Gaza. Sezer emphasized need for an equitable solution beyond two-state solution, focusing on supporting Palestinians’ right to determine their own fate. Dr. Zatari criticized labeling of anyone who opposes Israel’s illegal occupation of Palestine as anti-Semitic explained how Israel uses terms like ‘threat’, ‘holocaust’, ‘victim’ to justify its actions suppress discussions on Palestinian rights.

title: Deputy Minister Mahmut Gürcan Discussed Turkey’s e-Commerce and Entrepreneurship Vision at IZU
content: Deputy Minister Mahmut Gürcan Discussed Turkey’s e-Commerce Entrepreneurship Vision at 22.10.2025 At "Digital Economy Entrepreneurship Meeting" hosted by Zaim Technopark, role of e-commerce entrepreneurship in Turkey's economy, innovative business models, global competition strategies were discussed during digital transformation process. Deputy Minister of Trade Mahmut Gürcan was guest speaker at "Turkey's e-Commerce Entrepreneurship Vision" program held at Campus. The event, organized in collaboration with Zaim Technopark, Entrepreneurship Leadership Application Research Center, Entrepreneurship Club, E-Commerce Club, took place at Zaim Technopark Conference Hall. It was attended by Vice Rector Technopark General Manager Prof. Dr. İsmail Küçük, Director of Entrepreneurship Center Dr. Tuğçenur Ekinci Furtana, academics, students. The event covered developments in e-commerce entrepreneurship , oppurtunities for new entrepreneurs, initiatives for tech entrepreneurs, planning around cargo return processes. KÜÇÜK: “WE WANT TO INSPIRE YOUNG PEOPLE TO INVENT NEW THINGS” In his speech during program, Prof. Dr. İsmail Küçük, Vice Rector, emphasized that e-commerce e-export are two of most important dynamic topics in today’s economy, pointing out how digital marketplaces open new opportunities for entrepreneurs. He stated, “A product made in Anatolia is being distributed worldwide through innovations created by young people. This dynamic process greatly contributes to national economy. Through such meetings, we want to inspire young people who will ‘invent new things’.” GÜRCAN: "AS TECHNOLOGY ADVANCES, LAWS LAG BEHIND" Deputy Minister Mahmut Gürcan mentioned that it’s possible to divide world into two parts—before after pandemic. He highlighted how e-commerce experienced rapid growth during this period. He said, “It wasn’t just technological advancements that accelerated; entire trade process, including customer behaviors, changed. By end of 2024, Turkey’s e-commerce volume will reach 3 trillion TL, which is about 6.5% of Gross Domestic Product. E-commerce is a rapidly growing dynamic sector. There are critical aspects, like ensuring fair competition protecting consumer rights. As technology progresses, laws are lagging behind. We are working to ensure that legal framework accommodates these changes.” DEPUTY MINISTER MAHMUT GÜRCAN MEETS WITH RECTOR Following "Turkey’s e-Commerce Entrepreneurship Vision" program at Zaim Technopark, Deputy Minister Mahmut Gürcan was hosted by Rector Prof. Dr. Ahmet Cevat Acar. Vice Rectors Prof. Dr. İsmail Küçük Prof. Dr. Nihat Erdoğmuş also attended meeting, during which information was shared about university's entrepreneurship, R&D, Technopark activities.

title: Patent and Trademark Disputes Discussed
content: Patent Trademark Disputes Discussed 22.10.2025 At patent trademark dispute panel organized by Faculty of Law at IZU, changes brought about by artificial intelligence in intellectual property its future impacts were discussed. The "Patent Trademark Disputes from a Practitioner's Perspective" panel, organized by İstanbul Sabahattin Zaim University Faculty of Law, took place at Abdullah Tivnikli Conference Hall. The events was attended by Prof. Dr. M. Zeki Durak, President of Turkish Patent Trademark Office, Prof, Dr. Erhan İçener, Vice Rector of IZU, Dr. Halit Serhan Ercivelek, Vice Dean of Faculty of Law, Prof. Dr. Canan Küçükali, judges, academics, students. Experts in field discussed current Supreme Court rulings legal issues encountered in practice within framework of Intellectual Industrial Property Law. Dr. Halit Serhan Ercivelek, Vice Dean of Faculty of Law, expressed his pleasure in hosting such an important event. DURAK: "Brand Value Surpasses All Economic Values" Prof. Dr. M. Zeki Durak, President of Turkish Patent Trademark Office, highlighted that Turkey is second country after China in terms of geographic indications ranked twelfth in patent applications. He emphasized, “Our main agenda as an institution is technology investments legal regulations. Industrial property is becoming increasingly important every day. Brand value has surpassed all other economic values.” İÇENER: "Patents Trademarks Are Key to Turkey's Development" Prof. Dr. Erhan İçener, Vice Rector of IZU, also stressed that patents, trademarks, geographic indications are among most important indicators of Turkey's development. He added, “These topics are key to inter-country competition. Such meetings bring new perspectives to problems faced in field contribute to solutions. We are aware of importance of issue are happy to be part of this search for solutions.” CALBOLİ: "The Future Will Be Defined by AI Intellectual Property" Prof. Dr. Irene Calboli, guest speaker from Texas A&M University, addressed topics of artificial intelligence intellectual property ownership in her presentation titled “Commercial Trademark Patent Disputes in 2025.” She pointed out fundamental conflicts between protectability of AI-generated content intellectual property responsibility rules. She noted that this trend leads to intersections between copyright, patent, data protection laws. Calboli also emphasized that trademark disputes are not only legal issues but also sociological ones, stating, “The future will be defined by artificial intelligence intellectual property issues.” Throughout day, experts in field explored trademark patent disputes through practical examples.

title: STK's and Student Clubs Meet at İZÜ Campus
content: STK's Student Clubs Meet at İZÜ Campus 22.10.2025 Organized in collaboration Turkey Volunteer Associations Foundation (TGTV), Union of Civil Society Organizations of Islamic World (İDSB), Istanbul Sabahattin Zaim University, STKFest’25 kicked off at İZÜ Stadium. The opening ceremony of event, theme 'Support Gaza,' was attended by Istanbul Governor Davut Gül, Consul General of Bangladesh in Istanbul Muhammad Mizanur Rahman, İZÜ Board of Trustees Chairman Özkan Göksal, Deputy Chairmen Mustafa Büyükabacı İsrafil Kışla, Istanbul University-Cerrahpaşa Rector Prof. Dr. Nuri Aydın, Haliç University Rector Prof. Dr. Nihat İnanç, İZÜ Rector Prof. Dr. Ahmet Cevat Acar, Vice Rectors Prof. Dr. İsmail Küçük, Prof. Dr. Erhan İçener, Prof. Dr. Nihat Erdoğmuş, İZÜ Secretary General Dr. Fatih Hasdemir, Istanbul Provincial Director of National Education Murat Mücahit Yentür, Küçükçekmece District Governor Mustafa Anteplioğlu, Küçükçekmece District Director of National Education Emin Çıkrıkçı, TGTV Founders Board Chairman Hamza Akbulut, TGTV Executive Management Board Chairman İsmail Tuğrul, İDSB General Secretary Eyüp Akbal, along STK executives, academics, students. The event, which was combined İZÜ's 15th Club Opening Festival, brought together student clubs from İbn Haldun, Istanbul Commerce, Haliç Universities TGTV-member STKs public institutions. The program aims to strengthen cooperation STKs, promote volunteerism, build a culture of social solidarity. A Hope Tree Was Planted Gaza The festival kicked off “Planting a Hope Tree Gaza” “Silence March Gaza” events, attended by Governor Davut Gül protocol members, along 29 STKs, public institutions, student clubs from universities. In opening speech, İZÜ Student Affairs Clubs Department Head Hülya Şekerci thanked all participants, saying, "In an era where individuality is emphasized, we are searching ways to be 'together'." TGTV Executive Management Board Chairman İsmail Tuğrul also expressed hope that this first edition of STKFest would become a tradition, highlighting importance of walking together to connect youth. He said, "We are seeking answers to question 'How can we grow together?' Here, youth are hosts, STKs are guests." Rector Acar: The Active Role of STKs is Important Contribution of Society to Public Administration İDSB General Secretary Eyüp Akbal stated that "STKFest is not just an event, but an awakening of thought conscience" expressed satisfaction in uniting energy of youth conscience of STKs. TGTV Founders Board Chairman Hamza Akbulut reminded that we are heirs of a foundation civilization. İZÜ Rector Prof. Dr. Ahmet Cevat Acar then spoke, emphasizing that one of functions of universities is to serve society. He noted that İZÜ has been acting this awareness 15 years. Acar continued, "The active presence of STKs in a country is important contribution of society to public administration. But perhaps equally important is role they play in providing services that governments are unable to deliver, both domestically internationally. Their mission during genocide, which we have been horrified to witness past two years, is clearest evidence of this." Governor Gül: We Will Continue to Uphold 'World Is Bigger Than Five' Claim Istanbul Governor Davut Gül pointed out significance of festival, which was held first time this year. He said, "As in our tradition, civil society awareness is very high today. Through STKs, we reach all corners of world, standing by those in need oppressed. For STKs to work towards their goals, they need human capital volunteers. This task primarily falls on all of us, especially youth. Your support is crucial significant continuing claim 'The World Is Bigger Than Five,' as expressed by our President." After ribbon-cutting ceremony, protocol visited booths set up by nearly 40 institutions, STKs, student clubs. The first day of festival concluded a piano recital, a poetry competition using artificial intelligence, other activities. The festival will continue on its second day competitions, award ceremonies, a "Brotherhood Dinner.

title: İZÜ Participated in the 15th UNSA Study Expo Held in Sarajevo
content: İZÜ Participated in the 15th UNSA Study Expo Held in Sarajevo 27.10.2025 Istanbul Sabahattin Zaim University (İZÜ) participated in the 15th UNSA Study Expo , hosted by the University of Sarajevo . As part of the event, the İZÜ delegation visited the University of Sarajevo and met with Vice-Rector Prof. Dr. Kemal Durić to exchange views on enhancing academic and cultural cooperation between the two institutions. The fair brought together 49 institutions from 21 different countries , providing a platform for establishing various connections and collaborations related to international partnerships and student exchange programs.

title: The Delegation from Malaysia Tawau Teacher Education Institute Visited IZU
content: The Delegation from Malaysia Tawau Teacher Education Institute Visited IZU 03.11.2025 Istanbul Sabahattin Zaim University hosted an academic delegation from Malaysia Tawau Teacher Education Institute. The delegation, led by Abdul Hamid bin Abdul Rahim, Head of Department of Strategic Programs, Research and Innovation, included Richeal Phil Thien Kim How, Head of International Relations Unit; Hajah Rosnah Abdul Razak, Program Assistant; Jamilah binti Ahmad, Head of STEM Department; Hajah Latifah binti Monnas, Head of Educational Sciences Department; and Lim Fui Chiew, Head of Physical Education Department. title: The "Philosophy for Children" Program was held at IZÜ
content: "Philosophy for Children" Program was held at IZÜ 27.10.2025 "4th philosophy for Children Workshop," organized by New Turkey Education Foundation (YETEV) in collaboration with Istanbul Sabahattin Zaim University (İZÜ), focused on theme of "Philosophy Family" this year. importance of family in raising individuals who think critically reflectively was emphasized during program. "4th Philosophy for Children Workshop" (ÇİF), organized by YETEV İZÜ, took place at İZÜ Abdullah Tivnikli Conference Hall. workshop featured speakers Prof. Yaylagül Ceran Karataş from Istanbul Medeniyet University Prof. Enis Doko from Ibn Haldun University. event was attended by İZÜ Rector Prof. Ahmet Cevat Acar, Vice Rector Prof. Erhan İçener, YETEV Shools General Manager Hayati Oktay, administrators teachers from workshop was "Philosophy Family." OKTAY: THE FAMILY IS THE BEGINNING SHCOOL OF PHILOSOPHY In his opening speech, YETEV Schools General Manager Hayati Oktay highlighted "Philosophy for Children" lessons, which started in 2021, now cover all students from second to seventh grade at YETEV-affiliated shcools. Referring to Newton's questioning of why an apple falls to ground, Oktay pointed out how this simple question changed course of world. He continued: "Since Socrates, humanity has been seeking answers to question 'why'. first institution where this question found meaning is family, starting school of philosophy. Our goal is to raise students who ask, question, approach life with critical thinking." ACAR: IT IS IMPORTANT TO KNOW WHERE WE ROOT OURSELVES Prof. Ahmet Cevat Acar, Rector of İZÜ, emphasized negative impact on children's intellectual mental development when their questions are left unanswered. He stated it is impossible for someone suspends their critical thinking to become a good person, good citizen, or good Muslim. Reminding philosophy is not limited to activities of ancient Greek thinkers, Acar emphasized importance of guiding people from our own beliefs cultural world. He said, "It is important where we root ourselves. We have all seen where Western civilization has led humanity. values of Islamic civilization must be passed on to new generations, this is more important than we might think." KARATAŞ: THE FAMİLY IS A WAY OF BEING TOGETHER first speaker of workshop, Prof. Yaylagül Ceran Karataş from Istanbul Medeniyet University, addressed question "What is family?" in her talk titled "What is what is Not Family in Context of Ethics, Political Economy, Technology." She argued family should be considered not only in its social context but also in its existential aspect. "When talking about family, we first need to clear our mindes of informational conceptual pollution," Karataş stated, emphasizing family cannot be reduced to a stucture consisting only of a contract between mother, father, child. She noted genocides are not only committed with weapons, we must recognize we have also been subjected to political epistemological genocides. "We need to redefine our concepts before discussing topics, including family," she said. She also pointed out family, which was defined as an institution after Industrial Revolution, cannot be reduced to this definition, Western-centric political economy technological developments have transformed family. " family is a form of relationship, a way of being together. It forms a larger structure includes neighborhood. To create a world, we must first define our own concepts," Karataş concluded. PHILOSOPHY FOR CHILDREN TALKS Following opening speech, "Philosophy for Children (ÇİFx) Talks" session discussed role of family in raising thinking individuals transformative effects of digital age on concept of a family. session featured Doç. Rıdvan Karabulut, Director of Social Sciences Vocational School at Kayseri University, Doç. Esra İleri Türk, a faculty member at Istanbul Sabahattin Zaim University's Faculty of Islamic Sciences. After session, participants moved on to workshop activities. workshops, which included topics such as “Responsibility Trust in Family,” “Critical Thinking in Digital World: Ways to Guide Children,” “The Silent Language of Bond: Role, Value, Inquiry Experience in Family,” “What is Truth Friendship?”, “The Dialectic of Thinking: Problem Solving, Critical Thinking, Decision Making in Age of Artificial Intelligence,” “Thinking About Existence with Adults: Child, Mole, Fox, Horse,” “Oh No, Children Are Asking Questions!”, were followed by a closing session. "BEING A FAMILY IN THE MODERN AGE" guest speaker for closing session was Prof. Enis Doko from Ibn Haldun University’s Department of Philosophy. In his speech titled "The Family as a School of Wisdom," Doko discussed reasons consequences of family increasingly being viewed as a mere contract or temporary choice in modern age. He emphasized family is not just a social institution but also a fundamental environment shapes identity, virtues, spirituality. By comparing views of contemporary philosophers with approaches of Sufism, Doko argued family is a space where human values such as loyalty, compassion, sacrifice, responsibility are learned. workshop concluded with presentation of gifts to workshop trainers participants.

title: Cooperation Agreement Between IZU and Sudan
content: Cooperation Agreement Between IZU Sudan 03.11.2025 The Consul General of Republic of Sudan in Istanbul delegation from Sudanese Community in Istanbul visited our university. The delegation included Osaman Mahjoub, Consul General of Republic of Sudan in Istanbul; Prof. Dr. Nizar Ata, President of Sudanese Community in Istanbul; Naji El Karshabi, Secretary of Media Public Relations Official Spokesperson of Community; Dr. Magda Cafer, Secretary of Women Children's Unit; Oatada Kamal, President of Turkish Sudanese Students Union; Ahmed Ammar, President of Istanbul Sudanese Students Association. The meeting was attended by IZU Rector Prof. Dr. Ahmet Cevat Acar; Vice Rectors Prof. Dr. İsmail Küçük Prof. Dr. Erhan İçener; Acting Director of IZU TÖMER Lecturer Nurhilal Emre; International Office Coordinator Nesibe Aloudatallah Ghadban. During meeting, strengthening relations between IZU Sudanese community was discussed. The participants also evaluated opportunities for increasing mutual academic cultural exchange explored potential future joint projects. Additionally, a consensus was reached on cooperation in language education through Turkish language courses offered by IZU TÖMER for Sudanese students.
